repnme.cdata!:
Kyrgyz Republic - Sheep and Wool
            Improvement Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated satisfactory.
            Sustainability is rated unsatisfactory: The sustainability
            ratings take into account the overall institutional
            insecurity in this transition country, the uncertainties
            about future government funding, and the particular
            sustainability of institutions and investments. Overall,
            those investments that reached farmers (genetics, local
            pasture leasing, private veterinary care, and selected local
            cooperatives) are considered sustainable and may further
            expand. Investments that depend on government funding are
            more tenuous, as budget support is insecure and governmental
            institutions are prone to interference. Bank performance is
            rated satisfactory overall. Borrower performance is rated
            unsatisfactory: Overall, the Borrower's performance can
            be characterized as ambivalent, from a period where the
            Government wanted to close the project, to periods of solid
            support. Moreover, substantial differences of opinion
            between MAWRPI (the designated implementation agency) and
            the Ministry of Finance (MoF) regarding project direction
            and implementation led to much uncertainty, many delays and,
            finally, to MoF involving itself in technical issues outside
            the professional competence of the concerned staff, which
            caused further delays. Lessons learned included the
            following: 1) Sectoral investment during a time of major
            farm restructuring or institutional reform, where the
            outcome is by no means clear, carries a substantial risk of
            making wrong investment decisions. In this particular case,
            many project beneficiaries were still undergoing changes in
            physical and legal asset ownership, and the shape of the
            industry substantially changed during implementation.
            Consequently, some investments identified at appraisal were
            not feasible. 2) The project was appraised in a country that
            was used to a centrally planned investment climate, and that
            paradigm persisted in many minds and in the procedures of
            the implementing agencies. Ministries, stakeholders and the
            general public were not well informed about development in
            general, or about the specific development objectives of the
            project. This was later somewhat corrected, but most early
            project investments appear to have focused on supporting
            state farms. 3) Flexibility in implementation greatly helped
            to overcome some of the weaknesses of design. Such
            flexibility is highly recommended for investment projects
            during transition, because it allows time and room for
            learning while doing. 4) The international technical
            assistance for establishing project management capacity in a
            country without such experience proved valuable, with
            benefits that extended to subsequent IDA-funded projects in
            MAWRPI and other ministries. 5) Investment in hardware
            (laboratory equipment, liquid nitrogen machine, etc.)
            without investment in operating skills leads to procurement
            of goods that are either not suitable or are under-utilized
            and as such a waste or resources. 6) long term commitment to
            inexperienced consultants should be avoided, and (ii)
            Employment of consultants to work with institutions that
            they worked for in the immediate past should be designed
            with care to avoid conflict of interest.

5081031.trustfund:
TF022691-PHRD-AGRICUL.REFORM IMPLEMENT.SUPPORT,TF036363-ECA REGION - DISTRICT HEATING
            AND POWER PROJECTS (LITHUANIA,,TF023330-SIDA CTF FOR EASTERN EUROPE,TF039251-KYRGYZ REPUBLIC - SHEEP
            DEVELOPMENT PROJECT
5081031.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Environment and natural resource management,Rural development

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Sheep Development
            Project are to: 1) increase the profitability and efficiency
            of sheep and wool farming; 2) privatize the provision of
            several services to farmers, including wool marketing and
            veterinary services; and 3) improve the management and
            conservation of natural grazing resources by farmers. To
            achieve these objectives, the project will focus on: 1)
            organizing sheep and wool farmers into farmers'
            associations or groups through which essential services can
            be channeled; 2) developing a competitive marketing
            structure with incentives for production of quality lambs
            and wool for premium prices; 3) increasing sheep and wool
            productivity through establishing training and advisory
            services for private farmers and supporting selected
            breeding activities; and 4) developing and disseminating
            sustainable pasture management techniques among sheep
            producers. The project consists of three main components: 1)
            sheep private enterprise development, including: (a) sheep
            producers' groups/associations; (b) regional sheep
            breeders associations; (c) Kyrgyz sheep breeders
            associations; (d) wool and lamb marketing; and (e) wool
            testing; 2) development of livestock support services, which
            comprises: (a) project implementation unit; (b) agricultural
            training and advisory services; and (c) animal health
            services; and 3) sheep breeding research support involving
            sheep breeding research and pastures land resources.
